activity.text:
Takes like this are literally true but I think miss the mark by a long way.

New knowledge is generated by conjecture and refutation. A synthetic data generation system is essentially the conjecture part. You just have to add some way to filter/score the generations.

quoted.text: @sharongoldman @CohereAI @aidangomezzz Training on synthetic data cannot lead to new knowledge discoveries. Training on synthetic data is a process of transforming one representation of knowledge into another. Any knowledge discovered by the second system must be implicit in the data generator. 1/

activity.text: @RazRazcle But refutation (falsification) comes from data and experiments if the conjecture has empirical content.

replyTo.text:

Are they approximating nearest neighbours in significantly different ways?

I'm aware of accelerated NN search algos like KD-trees or Orchard's algorithm but nothing approximate and would love to learn!

quoted.text:
Why you should never use pgvector (e.g. @supabase Vector Store) for production:

üòÆ pgvector is 20x slower than a decent vector DB (e.g. @qdrant_engine)

activity.text:
Contrary to popular opinion, I see a lot of companies finetuning LLMs.

They just tend to do it after things are working. 
Start with prompt engineering, solve a real customer need and then optimise.

@RazRazcle Right. This is why I think the "just a wrapper on GPT" is the wrong way to think about it. The best talent I see start that way, iterate to find a product that resonates, then take on the cost/complexity of training their own models.

replyTo.text: @Fraser A lot before the release of functions from OpenAI but that was more of a hack. Mostly open source.

activity.text:

activity.text:
A good way to understand Exponentials:

1 million seconds ago was 11 days ago.
1 billion seconds ago was 1992 (31 years ago). 
1 trillion seconds ago was 31,000 B.C.

@RazRazcle @akashmjn @PeterDiamandis Point is I don't think he was talking about *growth*. 
He was just giving an analogy to show how big these numbers are that we casually toss about.

replyTo.text: @bill_tirrill @akashmjn @PeterDiamandis That is both a list of powers and a geometric progression. Subsequent terms grow by a constant factor of 10^3.  Exponential growth is growth proportional to current size. Technically this progression is growing exponentially but the tweet doesn't aid understanding.

activity.text: @bill_tirrill @akashmjn @PeterDiamandis Fair enough but as I said originally,  what does that have to do with exponentials. I think the answer is very little.  It's an important topic and I think this impedes understanding.

replyTo.text:
@RazRazcle @akashmjn @PeterDiamandis Point is I don't think he was talking about *growth*. 
He was just giving an analogy to show how big these numbers are that we casually toss about.

activity.text: @RazRazcle @akashmjn @PeterDiamandis I think he's talking about powers, not progressions. 10^6, 10^9, 10^12 ...

replyTo.text: @akashmjn @PeterDiamandis If you concede the first point the second obviously follows. Something that's wrong is not a helpful guide to understanding...

activity.text: @eshear Yeah, in high dims samples near the mode become pretty rare. E.g think of flipping a biased coin 100 times with p_heads=0.9. 100 heads is the mode but there's only 1 way to achieve it. Many more ways to achieve other combinations even if they're less probable.

quoted.text:
I have claimed that Auto-Regressive LLMs are exponentially diverging diffusion processes.
Here is the argument:
Let e be the probability that any generated token exits the tree of "correct" answers.
Then the probability that an answer of length n is correct is (1-e)^n
1/ https://t.co/BTd9Hro7gi

activity.text:
@IntuitMachine @ylecun So what he's really saying is that it's very hard to make long autoregressive LLMs be factually correct.

For what its worth I don't agree and think the argument has simplified too much.

replyTo.text:
@IntuitMachine @ylecun His argument is that for autoregressive models, errors accumulate. So the longer the length of the chain the more likely it is that an LLM makes a factual error.

Worse than this the probability of error multiplies so the  probability of error grows exponentially in length.

activity.text: 1/ The simplest possible prompt is a "zero-shot" instruction prompt. You just ask the model to do what you want. This works *ok* but the model still has a tendency to make things up and it doesn't know about changing world events or private info. https://t.co/b3BM3mPdQM

activity.text:
It's wild to me that when considering resources people don't consider the benefits at all.

Resource consumption in NLP (both $ and carbon) is absolutely tiny. Even if you think these models don't "understand" language, they're being used by millions of people in useful products.

quoted.text: It's wild to me that this is considered a picture of "progress". Progress towards what? What I see is a picture of ever increasing usage of resources + complete disinterest in being able to document and understand the data these things are build on.
